name: O'Connors Bar
description:
City: Thornton Cleveleys
description: A cult venue, down to earth and ungentrified. Office-type panels by the ceiling, cheap but lived-in cosiness. Not for the faint hearted by the sounds of it, but a bit of a one-off.

name: The Whitestone Inn
description:
City: Ballasalla
description: A typical market place pub with a low ceiling and village life.

name: The Grey Bull
description:
City: Stanhope
description: An unspoilt simple country boozer with plenty of room for drinking only. Looks very nice in its simple way.

name: The Blue Bell Inn
description:
City: St John's Chapel
description: Pleasant looking country pub in a stone cottage.

name: The Wainwright Pub
description:
City: Keswick
description: Cosy and lived in pub with wooden beams, pump clips and beer mats everywhere.

name: George & Dragon
description:
City: Lichfield
description: Traditional high street pub with cosy bench seating around the bar. Characterful brick exterior and beams in side rooms. Attractive looking beer garden.

name: Bitter-Suite Micropub
description:
City: Lichfield
description: High street micropub. Down to earth homely interior with some old fashioned pub games.

name: The Ashton
description:
City: Helensburgh
description: High street real ale venue with a local crowd.

name: Zoiglstubn beim Brucksaler
description:
City: Neustadt
description: Part of the fine tradition of zoiglstubn where a communal brewhouse is shared and a family restaurant opens on rotation. A more bland setup than some on our 2023 visit, though the beer itself is interesting, as is the community surrounding this tradition. Hospitality is friendly and welcoming. (updated August 2023)

name: Zoiglwirtschaft Zum Waldhauser
description:
City: Neustadt
description: Part of the fine tradition of zoiglstubn. Visit as soon as you can.

name: Zoiglstubn zum Mundl
description:
City: Stornstein
description: Part of the fine tradition of zoiglstubn. Visit as soon as you can. Check to see if it's open before travelling here.

name: Old Doctor Butler's Head
description:
City: London
description: Plenty of old wood and historical appeal at this boozer in the banking district run by Shepherd Neame.

name: Caniço
description:
City: Alvor
description: A one off. Its terrace has a unique view looking out onto the bay. Very popular and of course in fairly high demand.

name: Old Swan Inn
description:
City: Netherton
description: AKA 'Ma Pardoes'. A town pub that hasn't had its layout gutted to become open plan and characterless. Cosy siderooms with studded leather bench seats. The wallpaper and paintjob is a little tacky but overall the pub retains its necessary character.

name: Na staré kovárně
description:
City: Prague
description: A new venture by a local music group, it's a cafe bar with a bit of extra attitude and more contemporary beer options.

name: Vagabund Brauerei
description:
City: Berlin
description: A contemporary brewery tap but that's also a neighbourhood local. Modern but seemingly done well. Exceptionally well reviewed.

name: Na Kovárně
description:
City: Velhartice
description: Rustic country inn that looks part workshop as well as pub. Concessions to progress are kept to a minimum and there's clear a dash of local character too. The beer options look excellent and cheap.

name: The Prince Of Wales
description:
City: Stow Maries

description: A pub that's clearly also the heart of the community. Community takes precedence as can be seen from everything above it. Loved and lived in, without being spectacular.

name: Fat Cat Ipswich
description:
City: Ipswich
description: Down to earth welcoming boozer with a conservatory at the back and characterful (if poorly decorated) bar area. Very popular and with good reason, seemingly.

name: Dove Street Inn Ipswich
description:
City: Ipswich
description: Another corner boozer/micropub that may not have the historical appeal or furnishings to set a tone as a proper pub, but does have the drinks and community around it. Looks good.

name: The Odd One Out
description:
City: Colchester
description: A terrific looking free-house in beautiful brick building. A community hub and almost frozen in time feel. Looks very cosy and highly likely to score well with us.

name: New Inn
description:
City: Colchester
description: Another characterful looking community pub with a deliberately ramshackle but homely appearance, real ales and extensive whisky selection.

name: The Compasses
description:
City: Littley Green

description: Fantastic country pub with a real traditional tavern feel, through its tiled floor and wooden bar area. Looks excellent.

name: Brewery Tap Sudbury
description:
City: Sudbury
description: While there are some bland design choices, quirks such as historic pub games and of course the brewery tap make it look like a solid community-boozer.

name: The Station Arms
description:
City: Southminster
description: A well kept 'station pub' with a lively community feel. Local but friendly looking. Excellent reviews.

name: King William IV
description:
City: Braintree
description: Lively looking community pub with large beer garden.

name: The Carpenters Arms
description:
City: Maldon
description: German beer and cider abound in this genteel sizeable pub. Looks lovely.

name: Farmers Yard
description:
City: Maldon

description: Micro and bottle shop with attractive wooden bench seats and panels. Exactly what you are looking for from this type of thing.

name: The Boars Head
description:
City: Stockport
description: Sam Smiths pub decorated in traditional style. We gave it a go in 2022, perhaps needs a further visit to decide. (Added July 2021)

name: Zum Dürnbräu
description:
City: Munich
description: Expensive but characterful looking beer hall on the site of a historic - but defunct - brewery. On our first visit it was too quiet to reach a real impression, but looked to have some potential for winter.

name: Tap-House
description:
City: Munich
description: 40 taps, you will not go wrong in the task of finding a beer you'd like to drink. We have visited but aren't sure this place deserves inclusion. Decor is bland and the seating options (all stools) make it less relaxed than it ought to be. There are positives though, so it's on the fringes for now.

name: Gasthaus Neue Welt "Aris"
description:
City: Nordlingen
description: A distinctive pub with wooden beams, low ceilings and white tiles. Very down to earth with scarves of local football teams and a youngish crowd interested in a beer and a chat. Games are available too, along with Sky sports, so it really is a drinking kneipe primarily. We felt it just didn't quite have enough overall to stand out as worthy of inclusion, but keep it here as a tentative recommendation.

name: Dideldum Pilsbar
description:
City: Rothenburg ob der Tauber

description: Despite 2 visits I haven't quite seen fit to add this to the guide. There is a lot to like. The Italian owner has the place running to a tee. She is friendly and her daughter helps in the evenings. The interior is plush and very distinctly un-Germanic, though it is also very clearly a pub and bar too. The place is a little bit of a throwback, and due to the lack of other options in town it tends to be very popular with youngsters. We can tentatively recommend.

name: The Raven
description:
City: Bath
description: Reasonably characterful old pub, well reviewed, decor a bit on the bland Laura Ashley side but furniture looks quite traditional.

name: The Bell Inn
description:
City: Bath
description: Live music in a friendly down-to-earth setting, by Bath standards of course. Looks good and is well reviewed.

name: Pivnice U Čiháků
description:
City: Podebrady
description: Looks like an absolutely excellent pivnice with great beer selection and characterful enough interior. The reviews speak highly of it too.

name: Bei Tina
description:
City: Munich
description: One of Munich's 'boazn', small pubs normally run by women of the house, dying out around the city.

name: Saddle Inn
description:
City: Douglas
description: Excellent quayside boozer with darts + pool. Looks to be down to earth and authentic as an alehouse.

name: Bulls Head
description:
City: West Clandon

description: A down to earth boozer with an attractive beer garden. Looks local and characterful enough with a distinctive bar area.

name: The Jolly Farmer
description:
City: Bramley
description: A barn-like pub strewn with beer mat and jug decorations on the walls and ceilings. Looks to have gone the extra mile to be distinctive, and is well reviewed.

name: Cafè Bar Catalunya
description:
City: Sant Cugat del Valles

description: Certain problems with service and price aside, the venue is a piece of history both in the decor and format, so can't be missed if in the area.

name: The Ship Inn
description:
City: Wincle
description: A real fire, wooden beams and thick carpets at this country pub. Gentrified a little and food-focused but still with some inn character.

name: The Lord Eldon
description:
City: Knutsford
description: Superb looking interior with black beams, brass decorations and characterful bar area. a real pub by the look of it.

name: The Star Inn
description:
City: St Just

description: Thoroughly cornish pub which looks homely and down to earth, distinctive with it.

name: The Guide Dog
description:
City: Southampton
description: Well reviewed community pub with a down to earth neighbourly feel. One for simple virtues rather than anything flashy, by the look of it. Nothing wrong with that.

name: Hostinec U Libuše
description:
City: Zakolany
description: Looks to be an excellently kept hospoda. Mid-brown wood-fit walls in the classic fashion, some homely decor and games. Looks versatile without being bland.

UPDATE - Looks like very little information since 2023 - could now be closed down

name: The Dysart Arms
description:
City: Bunbury
description: 19th century pub with oak beams and homely furnishings, bookcases and rugs. Fairly neat and tidy, there is still a hint of the open-plan bland dining pub but it nevertheless looks like a good venue.

name: The Ye Olde Rose & Crown
description:
City: Stafford
description: Joules pub with a nice distinctive character, not in the normal mould, not wildly out but still of its own thing. Wooden beams, fire, folk music nights.

name: The Arden Arms
description:
City: Stockport
description: Fine interior with parquet floor and red upholstered bench seating in traditional fashion. Robinsons place, popular spot. However, on our visit it was far too foodie and didn't feel like as welcoming place to go for a drink as it ought to have. We remain on the fence. (Added July 2021)

name: The Barley Mow Inn
description:
City: Kirk Ireton
description: Very distinctive country pub that hasn't done a bland cookie cutter template. Plenty of character in the layout and arrangement. Strong identity, and well reviewed.

name: The Royal Oak Laxfield
description:
City: Laxfield
description: Large timberframe building in the style of a coaching inn. Very much a village pub these days with large beer garden, meals, function rooms etc. The reviews tell of a quirky venue with good atmosphere and genial hosts.

name: The Kings Head (The Low House)
description:
City: Laxfield
description: Information about the pub rooms are thin on the ground, but this thatched cottage pub is well reviewed and all reason to believe there is a characterful, homely interior inside.

name: John Harvey Tavern
description:
City: Lewes
description: Tentative inclusion. While aspects do look cosy and nicely wooden and characterful, there is a bit of 00s grey paint and standardised decor in places. The proximity to Harveys brewery and reliability of a good pint may prop this  one up.

name: Colvile Arms
description:
City: Lullington
description: While a little genteel, there are some authentic characterful pub features in this village inn, could be worth dropping by. Very well reviewed and on CAMRA's national inventory of interiors.

name: Blue Bell Inn
description:
City: Newbiggin
description: Beautiful Dales cottage inn based in a remote hamlet. While of course surviving on food, this inn appears to have plenty of traditional character with tarred exposed beams, horse brasses, a fireplace and homely decor. Very well reviewed.

name: Hyltn
description:
City: Oldris
description: A supposedly legendary operation with an original innkeeper. Looks like a typical functional out-in-the-sticks boozer, which is brought to life by its locals as opposed to its decor.

name: Roubenka Borová
description:
City: Borova
description: Attractive wooden cottage with typically rustic country decor in the courtyard and a cosy looks interior. Looks fine for both drinking and eating.

name: The Thorn Tree Inn
description:
City: Matlock
description: While under Greene King's control anything to do with this pub must have a pinch of salt taken with it. Nevertheless, with commanding views of the valley from the beer garden and an attractively cosy and compact interior, perhaps not even the awful GK can blandardise this one.

name: St Radegund Pub
description:
City: Cambridge
description: A tiny pub in traditional style (wooden, benches, etc) dedicated to Cambridge's rowers. Looks pretty good.

name: Barnabeer
description:
City: Namur
description: Popular beer mecca. Exposed brick, old beer signage, and stylish stucco ceiling designs, among other features. It looks like it will be a reliable all-rounder than love at first sight.

name: George Hotel, Youlgreave
description:
City: Youlgreave
description: A very much independent feel to this pub, fewer concessions to the corporate standardised norm. Everything is a little ad hoc, and probably for the better.

name: The Railwayman's Arms
description:
City: Bridgnorth
description: Wonderful station pub, decorated like the inside of a Pullman carriage, but even more amplified, it looks cosy and friendly. Very well reviewed.

name: The Victory Inn
description:
City: Staplefield
description: Attractive country inn with a genteel rustic decor inside, not cookie-cutter by any means (although the food looks rather generic). Even so, great reviews of the place.

name: Horní Újezd - Obecní Úřad
description:
City: Horni Ujezd

description: One of the fast vanishing municipal pubs, commonly owned and as simple and stripped back as that suggests. There to keep the community together.

name: The Pestle & Mortar
description:
City: Hinckley
description: Ad hoc decor, a mish-mash, a bit like a middle aged person trying to create a craft venue on the cheap, but with clearly a lot of community value and a great range of beer.

name: Crown & Kettle
description:
City: Manchester
description: Craft beers in a setting with impressive gothic interior decor and ceiling. The pub itself appears awkwardly fitted around it, but the appearance is distinctive enough to be very worth a look.

name: The Land Of Liberty, Peace & Plenty
description:
City: Heronsgate
description: Nice to see a drinks focused pub in a village, this one has an octagonal central bar with simple bench seats and horse brasses decor. Plenty of cask ales to choose from.

name: The Ypres Castle Inn
description:
City: Rye
description: A simple minimalist format works quite well here given the unusual setting and the tasteful choices of furniture and decor. Big beer garden and interesting beer choices from Germany.

name: The Turks Head Inn
description:
City: Gloucester
description: Typical micropub in appearance. Everything a tad off centre and ramshackle in a characterful way. Typically spartan when it comes to rules, so no phones allowed inside. UPDATE DECEMBER 2022 - May be moving location and closed for renovations.

name: Live & Let Live
description:
City: Cambridge
description: Lively free house, beautiful wooden decor. Local ales. It looks terrific.

name: Telford's Warehouse
description:
City: Chester
description: A large dockside venue recommended for its drinks and live music events. We didn't get the best of it last time but it remains on the recommended list from the back of the great reviews.

name: The Cavern of the Curious Gnome
description:
City: Chester
description: Reopened since covid, a fantasy-world take on a Belgian beer bar set in Chester's famous rows. Great reviews and we can't wait to go. (Added March 2023)

name: Die Wampe
description:
City: Spandau
description: Looks like the best bar in Spandau, certainly with a vampy, rock-bar aesthetic. A cool hang-out spot for playing card, pool etc and enjoying music.

name: The Red Lion
description:
City: Bromley
description: A very well reviewed 'old man pub' (is that what we're calling trad pubs now? Hope not). Proper pub, perhaps? Yes. A proper pub. Down to earth, lived in, not just a chain.

name: Foords
description:
City: Filey
description: Well known locally. Clearly not everyone's cup of tea, but if you like old, gnarled cosy pubs, this one looks like it should appeal.

name: The Nag's Head
description:
City: Malvern
description: A well-kept yet relatively unspoilt and ungentrified pub, give or take a few design choices. Simple wooden tables, carpeted, wooden beams and low ceiling. Great reviews.

name: Dun Cow
description:
City: Seaton
description: Other than glowing reviews, information is a little thin on the appearance of the interior. All reviews tell of a traditional and unspoilt north eastern boozer, no airs and graces.

name: Star & Garter Pub
description:
City: Bromley
description: An impressively ornate frontage gives way to an airier interior and large bar area with an array of cask and keg beer options. The decor is tasteful, in keeping with some of the original fitting without being dramatic. It looks like it might be viable for the guide, we'll see.

name: Foersters Feine Bier
description:
City: Berlin
description: A bar specialising in very high quality small batch traditional German brewing from Franconia and elsewhere. A bar stacked with steinkrugs on the shelves and pleasant retro signage and rustic wooden seating is also very clearly quite modern and clean, so while I doesn't have true gnarly rustic appeal it looks well worth a visit nonetheless.

name: Eckkneipe
description:
City: Berlin
description: A classic Schultheiss, red hoarding, corner neighbourhood Berlin pub, probably one of the most typical examples, and therefore well worth a visit to sample true Berlin pub culture. Very well reviewed.

name: Zum Goldenen Hahn
description:
City: Berlin
description: Notorious smokey kneipe for punks and crusties. Kind service and the sort of raw, almost unchanged atmosphere that's worth sample. If there was a nuclear strike you'd probably be able to come here to find everyone still alive, sucking on cancer sticks and downing the cheap, if awful Schultheiss. A sociological experience, if nothing else. Clearly not one that will appeal to many, but one that will definitely strongly appeal to some.

name: Settle Inn
description:
City: Stirling
description: Looks like a fab boozer with stone walls, curved ceiling and alehouse type options. If they can keep it homely and not tacky they're on to a winner.

name: Zum Schiffchen
description:
City: Koblenz
description: The evening kneipe in Koblenz. Still looks to have plenty of atmosphere and local life. Excellent reviews.

name: Im Rondellchen
description:
City: Cologne
description: Round, yes indeed, this is a circular pub and so quite an unusual, if still trad interior. You'll find this one is still an ungentrified popular evening pub serving Gaffel kolsch. Looks pretty good.

name: Früh Em Jan von Werth
description:
City: Cologne
description: We passed this several times without going in, but from our research it seems this is a local's pub, and a strong all-rounder rather than just a beer hall. A few amenities, corners for socialising and so on, and seems welcoming too, heads will not turn if you walk in here.

name: Im Tubak
description:
City: Konigswinter
description: While other pubs sadly appear boarded up in this one-horse tourist town, Im Tubak seems to be the last trad pub, or indeed pub of any real kind standing. Seems to be by locals, for locals, but not unwelcoming.

name: Kneipchen Nr.7
description:
City: Wernigerode
description: Although we didn't make it here, this pub looks like a similarly viable option to Tommis. An evening kneipe with local life, authenticity and a bit of something extra for cosiness and identity.

name: Gittis Bier-Bar
description:
City: Berlin
description: This quaint, personalised old kneipe is just the sort of thing we are looking for, a slice of local life that seems cosy and authentic. Evidently popular with a range of people.

name: Fussballkneipe Elfmeter
description:
City: Halle
description: Stuffed with sporting memorabilia and trinkets, this pub may not appeal to some but may strongly appeal to others. Looks authentic and a slice of local life. Decor looks reasonably good even without the football theme and all signs point to a popular pub with a strong identity.

name: Café Brohmers
description:
City: Halle
description: Brooding pub cafe with some nice Deco styling, known for live music performances on a small theatre-like stage.

name: The Wee Howff
description:
City: Paisley
description: A small cosy haunt with a nice layout and wooden fixtures. A few bland interior design choices but it does look overall like a superior venue, despite the wannabe Laura Ashley who bought the cushions and wallpaper.

name: Hodpoda U Jezzu
description:
City: Roztoky
description: A quite beautiful riverside setting lends this rustic pub a natural advantage already. However, with a nicely placed beer garden, and lodge style interior this is a very clearly superior effort for Czechia. Local beer and Bernard's offerings compliment an overall outstanding venue.

name: Guduls cafe Moorsel / De Zwette Zoal
description:
City: Moorsel
description: Moorsel's premier brown cafe/volkscafé.  A legit brown, preserved lived in interior that should be a national monument but we will probably find has been bulldozed, turned into a hair salon or just left empty any day now.

name: Café Stinne
description:
City: Asse-ter-heide
description: A wonderful country pub with a homely interior, some longstanding features, lived-in character and cast of rural locals.

name: Pivrnec
description:
City: Ostrava
description: If you want a real slice of old time industrial town life in Czechia, go here.

name: The Plough
description:
City: Little London / Tadley

description: Wooden beams, roaring fire, Ringwood beers. A rural country pub that zones in on what makes them so good.

name: The Eagle Inn
description:
City: Abbotts Ann

description: Even at first glance, a very impressive attempt to run a pub catering for all tastes, whether that's the wood panel boozer feel of the bar, the games rooms, beer garden, and food areas. It is all tied together well without feeling bland. Highly rated.

name: White House Hotel
description:
City: Peel
description: Sometimes 'proper pub' seems a little sneering, but not a bit of it here. This is a down to earth pub that's massively popular for its classic unpretentious and homely setup.

name: The Nag's Head
description:
City: Reading
description: One of those neo-rustic alehouses they have now with recovered antique furniture and bar mats/pump clips everywhere. It does look like an utter classic, itself situated in a mock tudor building. Beer choices abounding.

name: The Chequers
description:
City: Little Gransden

description: Slightly marred by tedious jingoism but plenty still to like about this 'proper pub' as the phrase goes. Ie - communal, social, homely, down to earth and beyond corporate bollocks. Occasional live music. Exceptionally well reviewed with a family line going back 65 years.

name: The Mallard Inn
description:
City: Worksop
description: Worksop deserves a break and what a pub this looks. An unreconstructed station pub with some real lived-in character, lots of cask ales and right next to the tracks.

name: Fez
description:
City: Margate
description: Exciting looking bar with carefully curated salvaged trinkets and ornaments. Looks like a standout for the county let alone Margate.

name: Brauerei Witzgall
description:
City: Hallerndorf
description: A family operation, here is a slice of authentic Franconia. Simplicity and honest endeavour. Go before it's gone.

name: The Crown & Sceptre
description:
City: Stroud
description: Real ale, live music and altogether unpretentious friendly looking venue with rave reviews

name: Prince Albert Inn
description:
City: Stroud
description: Made famous through the BBC's series Saving Britain's Pubs, the wonderful owners Lotte & Miles are tenants who run a thriving community venue with a diverse crowd and live music events.

name: The Island Queen
description:
City: London
description: A wonderfully well preserved bar area makes this place a point of interest, though we believe it is a tentative suggestion rather than a must-visit.

name: Quimet & Quimet
description:
City: Barcelona
description: Famously piddly little bodega with bottles stacked high. Hardly any tables but apparently the atmosphere in there when you get served is worth the effort.

name: The Rising Sun
description:
City: Gunnislake
description: Ungentrified, lived-in cosy pub with a nice garden, great views over the valley, real ciders and a community feel. Priceless.

name: The Miners Arms
description:
City: Mithian
description: Exceptionally well reviews, this one seems like an all-rounder. Plenty of food is sold but you'll find a real fire, cottage/inn type stylings with a low ceiling. Looks like one to explore.

name: The Old Bull
description:
City: Inkberrow
description: Timberframed village pub with exposed beams in the entire, fireplace and hearty food, so just what you're after with this sort of thing. Well reviewed overall.

name: The Crown Inn
description:
City: Chiddingfold
description: A venue to put on your Sunday best for, this is a splendid old timberframe building that does very upscale dining. However, a well preserved bar area, albeit with some dull upholstery manages to preserve an interesting slice of historic Inn culture. The ales look decent too. Worth a look.

name: The Golden Lion
description:
City: Rochford
description: Seemingly a strong example of a traditional simple English pub, wood fittings, worn in and cosy, looks like decent ale choices too - well reviewed.

name: Black Horse
description:
City: Clapton in Gordano

description: A village pub with a rural setting and beautiful garden. Tarred beams and low ceiling inside, along with some nice lived-in elements are strong signs .

name: U Neostichu
description:
City: Prague
description: Cult Smichov pub with a cast of locals and well off the normal tourist trail. Although it was very down to earth, on our October 2024 there was not much to it that stood out.

name: The Olde Boars Head
description:
City: Middleton
description: Tudor stylings in a simple wooden beamed setup that looks warm, cosy and a safe bet.

name: The Boat Inn
description:
City: Melton Mowbray

description: Excellent reviews about this sidestreet pub that in effect acts as the station pub. Local life, cosy warm inside, homely and unpretentious, ungentrified. Looks really nice.

name: Brauerei Drei Kronen
description:
City: Schesslitz
description: Great reviews of this Gasthof and brewery. Things done the old way, it seems. Or at least taking the best from the old ways.

name: Pebbles Tavern
description:
City: Watchet
description: A real-cider micropub with attractive bar area and distinctive personalised interior. Excellent reviews.

name: The Esplanade Club
description:
City: Watchet
description: The local residents are lucky to have not 1 but 2 distinctive venues. A really personalised bar area that's live in, another one of those that's like an extension of the owner, an exhibition of their personality. Live music events give this another string to its bow.

name: The Belleman Pub
description:
City: Bruges
description: Dated but authentic pub with cushioned seating - rare for Belgium. At certain times of the year you'll find regulars reoccupying the spaces the tourists normally take up.

name: Eagle Inn
description:
City: Salford
description: A potentially uneasy peace treaty between a traditional pub and modern influences seems to have been resolved successfully here. A first visit was spoilt by a bad group of people, but are prepared to give it another go or two.

name: The Crossways Inn
description:
City: Churt
description: A beautiful simple pub that has made an asset of its preserved features instead of ripping them out. Tiled floor, countryfied furnishings and the last thing you really expect in such a wealthy area.

name: The Surrey Oaks
description:
City: Newdigate
description: A large country inn with beer garden, petanque pitches, low-ceilinged interior with various barn-type rooms. Overall it looks a good all-rounder.

name: The Elms
description:
City: Burton upon Trent

description: Celebrated Bass pub with large signage outfront. Cosy, unglamorous but homely inside.

name: Manor Arms
description:
City: Broughton-in-Furness

description: This really looks like a classic English pub. Communal friendly, simple and run on an established format. No wonder the reviews are glowing. We look forward to visiting.

name: The Blue Anchor Inn
description:
City: Helston
description: Another Cornish pub that looks fantastic. Late medieval building, local ales, simple interior cosy with stone walls. Just what you'd be looking for from the area. Use it or lose it.

name: The Lower Angel
description:
City: Warrington
description: Real ales aplenty in this compact boozer. Looks decent.

name: The Mermaid Inn
description:
City: Hugh Town

description: Classic smuggler cove type pub with very attractive bar area alongside the predictable nautical nik naks

name: The Flying Childers Inn
description:
City: Stanton in Peak

description: Beams, tankers, rugs and rustic furniture. Seemingly largely unspoilt ungentrified country charm. Looks very nice.

name: Pivnice U Čiháků
description:
City: Podebrady
description: Excellent looking hospoda with a rotation of Czech and craft beer classics. The interior has a familiar feel but with some personal touches.

name: The Glimmer Man
description:
City: Dublin
description: Interesting blend of old and new here, with a Brixton style back yard but inside trad furnishings and some ornate fixtures and fittings. Looks pretty good, well reviewed and off the tourist trail.

name: Pheasant Inn & Caravan Park
description:
City: Harmby
description: A proper country inn by all accounts, old fashioned, homely and lived-in, excellently well reviewed. Looks good.

name: The Retreat
description:
City: Reading
description: Real ale haunt with a slight DIY/micro vibe. Very well reviewed.

name: The Bay Horse Inn
description:
City: Crakehall
description: An unchanged, unmodernised small town pub with home comforts and a local crowd. Looks pretty good, classic Yorkshire fare.

name: The Royal George
description:
City: Morton-on-Swale
description: Seemingly classic Yorkshire country pub with lived-in character. Cosy, carpeted joint with a real fire, snug rooms and home cooking.

name: Blacksmiths Arms, Broughton Mills
description:
City: Broughton Mills

description: High-end gastropub but in an arch-traditional pub setting that looks to have a bar area fitting our requirements.

name: Digby Tap
description:
City: Sherbourne
description: Wonderful looking pub with stripped back but homely charm. Lots of wood, retro signage, and a certain rustic throwback feel. Think Sheaf View, Sheffield.

name: Three Horseshoes Warham
description:
City: Warham
description: Seems to be still just enough cosy character left in this near-coastal pub which has been given one of those typical seafaring decoration. Well reviewed and placed here from a personal recommendation.

name: Waggon & Horses
description:
City: Ibstock
description: Another good Waggon & Horses, apparently. Looks like a preserved classic. Upholstered bench seats, bass, simplicity. An alehouse not a gastropub.

name: Modrá Hvězda
description:
City: Prague
description: A smoking throwback - the old school atmosphere of Prague's Smichov district. Staropramen on tap, dirt cheap prices, yellow walls, identity, passion and no pretension. In order to comply it is a 'club' and so be careful to ensure you have your airs and graces when entering.

name: Helwith Bridge Inn
description:
City: Helwith Bridge

description: A typical walkers pub, hard wearing carpet, dogs, fireplace, though some brighter areas taking advantage of the riverside view. Very well rated.

name: Im Goldenen Kessel
description:
City: Dusseldorf
description: Schumacher's most central bierhalle. Fairly good for this sort of thing.

name: - KLO -
description:
City: Berlin
description: A toilet themed pub. We'll leave that with you.

name: Estaminet De Brouwerij
description:
City: Izegem
description: Taproom for the nearby D'Oude Maalderij brewery. Tonnes of beer ephemera in a cosy wooden barn. Looks great.

name: The Blue Lion Inn, Pub and Restaurant with Accommodation
description:
City: East Witton

description: A fine old bar area with characterful brown wood. Certainly upmarket elsewhere in the pub but looks good and well reviewed.

name: The Robin Hood Inn
description:
City: Amblecote
description: A classic neighbourhood pub. A sense of familiarity, lived-in community value, typical upholstered bench seating and stools, several real ale pumps. Looks very nice.

name: The Wyche Inn
description:
City: Malvern
description: A classic pub layout with some half-timber structure to boot. Pool table and local life.

name: The Five Bells
description:
City: Bassingham
description: Fantastic-looking pub with chunky beams and hanging foliage, a free house with some character.

name: Středověká krčma
description:
City: Detenice
description: A barn dedicated to medievalism to great effect. Definitely a pub-restaurant rather than a boozer but a remarkable place considering it's in the middle of nowhere.

name: Pivnice Batalion
description:
City: Jicin
description: Long-standing classic boozer set up for local socialising. Down to earth and intended for fun. Cheap Staropramen is the main beer offering.

name: Tuckers Grave Inn & Campsite
description:
City: Faulkland
description: Looks absolutely exceptional. Excellent seemingly unchanged rustic country inn with large grounds and views and rickety preserved interior.

name: The Chequers Inn
description:
City: Laddingford

description: 15th century country pub, low beams, and suitably for drinking, not yet turned into a bland beige dining room.

name: Bodega Joserra
description:
City: Bilbao
description: Popular bodega with historic fittings and cosy huddled together atmosphere.

name: Siegl's PUB
description:
City: Wiener Neustadt

description: A rare sign of life in a quite dull city. A curved ceiling in a Czech pivnice style provides a homeliness and there's an impression this is somewhat of an instutition.

name: U STAREJCH HADRŮ
description:
City: Prague
description: A true basement dive bar from the camp horror signage outside to scuzzy furniture and decor inside. Table football, table tennis, arcade machines and so on. If it's your thing, you'll love it. Marmite factor: High

It was a little quiet on our first try in October 2023, but will give it another try.

(Added 2021)

name: Krčma na náměstí
description:
City: Tři Studně,
description: Wonderful country style Krcma, so lots of chunky wood, hearty food, roaring old fire with ceramic panels. The front room by the taps looks good if you just want a drink too.

name: U Opilého draka
description:
City: Žďár nad Sázavou
description: An absolutely superb looking pub with an interesting concept.

name: CRAFT BEER PUB - U Škvorů
description:
City: Čerčany
description: This is not your average swish modern cookie-cutter craft bar. The craft beer here and the pub itself is all about content not style. Excellent local beers and simple honest and homely, if amateur, surroundings.

name: Hostinec U Janečků
description:
City: Kadov
description: A lovely unspoilt village pub with some homely genteel decor that has a personal touch. Looks like the sort of operation that could have been going for centuries.

name: The Locks
description:
City: Geldeston
description: Canalside pub with a threatened future. Outside of that it looks ideal for a spring and summer visit with beautiful surroundings and ancient feeling interior.

name: Fosters Arms
description:
City: Bridgnorth
description: While short on good beers, this cosy old freehouse has a lot of other simple appeals from the unspoilt bar area to the pool table room. Without being flashy, it's a pub as it should be.

name: The Black Boy Inn
description:
City: Bridgnorth
description: A reasonably intact bar area in historic surroundings. Some good ales on tap too. Worth a look.

name: Oak Inn
description:
City: Oswestry
description: A compact real ale pub that is on the Bass beer trail. Simple inside but cosy in the huddle.

name: Black Lion
description:
City: Oswestry
description: Lovely-looking honest boozer with comfy upholstered bench seats and lots of real ales on tap. Well reviewed.

name: The Prince Of Wales
description:
City: Shrewsbury
description: A rather old fashioned working men's club vibe to this pub, but not necessarily a bad thing. Very well reviewed and good ales.

name: The Pot & Glass
description:
City: Yarm

description: Outstanding looking bar area with blackened wood, horse brasses and carved wooden bar front. Prides itself on being an honest, proper pub. Looks very nice.

name: The Black Bull Inn
description:
City: Ugthorpe
description: Very well reviewed country pub with lots of the usual trappings: exposed stonework, beams, thick carpet, hearty food (vg options) and real ale. Looks good.

name: Bouchon Comptoir Brunet
description:
City: Lyon
description: Super old-timer pub with framed photographs, worn in tables and cast of regulars.

name: CAFÉ COMPTOIR ABEL - Le plus vieux bouchon lyonnais
description:
City: Lyon
description: Super old-timer pub with framed photographs, worn in tables and cast of regulars.

name: La Clave de San Pedro
description:
City: Cadiz
description: Well rated bodega/bar for night-time socialising. Wooden beamed ceiling, some nice tiles and a bar, but this is no quaint middle aged place, it's lively.

name: DuckBar
description:
City: Brno
description: Whether this is worth a walk we aren't sure yet, but an enticing riverside setting with nice beer garden, mainly locals and quirky highly individual interior that's lived in and homely.

name: Kaffibarinn
description:
City: Reykjavik
description: Enduring bar café hybrid, that's good for a local beer. Well reviewed, solid all-rounder, we would say.

name: Kleine Glocke
description:
City: Cologne
description: A smaller scale beer hall (think Sunner im Walfisch) that looks pubby enough for beer and food. Cosy scale and as featured on Parts Unknown by Anthony Bourdain.

name: The Wentworth
description:
City: Sheffield
description: A preserved old Ward's pub with some classic Northern pub characteristics, real fireplaces, upholstered seats, etc. Seems to be a couple of interesting atrium areas too.

name: Poole Arms
description:
City: Poole
description: Beautiful green faienced tiles line the frontage of the pub. Of course, it's what's inside that really counts, and it looks like they have still kept a reasonably coherent mid-brown pub with fairly low ceilings and drinking atmosphere, not only dining. Worth a look, at least.

name: Hostinec U Tesaře
description:
City: Brno
description: Multitap pub with regional beers and craft on rotation. Fairly minimalist inside but with a few personal touches. It is mainly about the garden terrace here which has a bar itself. We enjoyed it on our visit in April 2024 but ultimately it didn't quite tip the balance for an inclusion. Nevertheless, one to consider if you're in the area. (Added 2022)

name: Gasthaus zum Sieg
description:
City: Vienna
description: This looks to be an absolute classic. Central European knajpa/hospoda with simple wood fittings, old timer decor and pub grub. Highly rated.

name: The Three Goats Heads
description:
City: Oxford
description: Warning: Sam Smiths owned.
Palatial and well preserved interior in this classic city tavern.

name: The Bear Inn, Oxford
description:
City: Oxford
description: A wood paneled genteel alehouse. Something about wood manages to be both minimalist and characterful at the same time, and this seems to find the right balance.

name: The Royal Oak Inn
description:
City: Wantage
description: Looks like a true boozer done well. Real ale for a good price, cosy lived-in surroundings, community feel and some amenities and games to go with it. We want to go!

name: Grosmont Crossing Club
description:
City: Grosmont
description: Interesting little bar that seems to make use of an old club premises. Very old school, information thin on the ground, however comes highly recommended.

name: Skehans
description:
City: London
description: Quirky free house with interior that has a hint of Eastenders' Queen Vic. Nice and lived-in with a mixed community, live music, nik naks and a decent bit more personalised than a lot of more central London offerings.

name: The Old Crown
description:
City: Hesket Newmarket

description: Outstanding looking village pub in stone cottage with a frozen in time feel around the bar area. Carpeted, with pool room, fire going, very unpretentious-looking.

name: Seven Stars, Falmouth
description:
City: Falmouth
description: Excellent looking pub with distinctive bar area and predictable coastal town heritage. Looks individual but clearly enjoys mainstream trade. Well reviewed.

name: The Cover Bridge Inn
description:
City: East Witton

description: Classic welcoming North Dales country pub with fireplace, carpets, low ceiling, radiating warmth and comfort, without the airs and graces you get with some dining rooms.

name: The Bull Inn
description:
City: West Tanfield

description: Beautiful beer garden with willow trees stone bridge and riverside views along with the local church and tower. Inside a solid not-yet-totally gentrified Yorkshire pub with real ales.

name: Stamford & Warrington
description:
City: Coalville
description: Information thin on the ground but reportedly one of the best 'basic' pubs in the country and a throwback to the 1960s. Marston Pedigree is the lynchpin beer on offer. This is either your idea of heaven or a bit unappealing. We shall see.

name: The Crown Tavern
description:
City: Bristol
description: Love it or hate it, one of those pubs, this one looks like it has barely changed since the 60s, but time has dealt so much damage that in such a way that it becomes almost perversely interesting again. We would give it a try.

name: Waggon & Horses
description:
City: Halesowen
description: Highly-reputed real ale pub in the suburbs with very attractive bar area, plenty of choice, and cosy carpeted surroundings. A place to hole up for the evening no doubt. We look forward to visiting.

name: The Crooked Tap
description:
City: Acomb
description: Looks to be a well done modern taproom, with, of course, good beer options, but also a decent enough setup to not feel stark and try-hard.

name: Blind Jack's Pub
description:
City: Knaresborough
description: Looks to be a successful craft beer pub, worthy of a try

name: Ye Olde Smugglers Inne
description:
City: Alfriston
description: Timberframed pub with genteel, rustic surroundings, and ancient looking bar area which seems to be the best part of the pub, given some rather bland painting choices elsewhere.

name: The Boat Inn
description:
City: Ashleworth
description: Extremely cosy old country pub with intimate feel around a narrow bar room, carpets and chunky furniture. Famous for good ciders. Well reviewed.

name: The Fountain Inn
description:
City: Ashurst
description: Idyllic country setting, the bar area keeps its olde world charm, assisted by the Inglenook fireplace, exposed brickwork and beams. Grade II listed building, with literary and pop culture connections. Old barn area features a skittle alley.

name: The Mug House Inn & Restaurant
description:
City: Bewdley
description: Historic inn, that has been changed substantially inside, however a reasonably tasteful bar area with tiled floor and rustic niches keep a bit of character going. With a nice beer garden and riverside view there is a lot of appeal remaining to accompany the old stories.

name: The Great Western
description:
City: Bewdley
description: Attractive, if minimalist ale house with a quality range of drinks and timeless simple storied layout that just avoids being too bland in its appearance. Very well reviewed.

name: The Three Tuns Inn
description:
City: Bishop's Castle
description: The taproom for Britain's oldest licensed brewery. In the mid-70s this was one of 4 home brew pubs left in the country. Cavernous venue divided into sections, wood floors, oak beams, bench seating and fireplaces dominate, with good views of the brewery building, perched as it is on the top of the town.

name: Lord Crewe Arms Hotel
description:
City: Blanchland
description: Very much a modern dining room for the most part rather than a pub, however medieval cellars in the Crypt Bar are worth exploring with a great selection of ales. A popular stop off for stargazers in the region noted for its lack of light pollution and clear skies.

name: Doffcocker Inn
description:
City: Doffcocker
description: As a quirk, this is a calendar pub with 365 panes of glass, 52 doors, 28 rooms, 12 rooms in the cellar and 7 bedrooms. No-one seems to know why. As far as pubgoing goes, this is a cosy suburban pub with attractive wooden bar area and upholstered seating, popular for boardgames, darts, occasional live music and Holt beers.

name: Cricketers Arms
description:
City: Boscombe
description: Suburban neighbourhood pub with Edwardian fittings and layout. Carpeted, pleasant niches and corners to relax and socialise. Comfortably and homely, well loved, and with a good reputation for well-kept beers.

name: Fisherman's Tavern
description:
City: Broughty Ferry
description: For a Scottish pub this doesn't look too bad at all. Low ceilings, panelled walls and original ornate fireplace. Decorated with nods to the nearby lifeboat station. Converted from three fisherman's cottages. Looks like that was a good decision.

name: The Tree Inn
description:
City: Stratton
description: Local ales in a historic building. Gnarled beams, carefully curated furniture and slate floor. A little bit on the foodie side but enough character to visit for a sit, a pint and a chat.

name: Kings Arms
description:
City: Stratton
description: A typical classic village pub for locals and regulars. Pool table, comfortable seating, fireplace, dartboard, simple non-fussy grub. Homely and lived-in.

name: The Preston Gate Inn
description:
City: Poughill
description: A simple classic Cornish pub. Lived-in, homely and well loved, with live music, simple pub grub, and a long bar area.

name: Cliff Inn
description:
City: Crich
description: Superb looking unspoilt village inn where the emphasis is on a comfy spot to rest up, no airs and graces. Looks distinctive and authentic.

name: The Red Lion
description:
City: The Red Lion
description: Part of Crich Tramway Village, this pub was moved brick by brick by the museum's volunteers and rebuilt on the site. Historic art nouveau facade with faence glaze and brick. This is the focal point of the Edwardian period village. Open only during museum hours, but well worth a look.

name: The Speedwell Bar
description:
City: Dundee
description: Preserved Edwardian L-shaped pub with 100+ whiskies and up to date selection of beers. Looks to be a real classic with bell-pushes, etched glass and Jacobean effect ceiling. On CAMRA's national inventory of historic interiors. Friendly conversations and socialising abound, sometimes live folk music too.

name: The Hidden Treasure Micropub
description:
City: Dymchurch
description: One of Kent's many recent micropubs, offering cosy intimate surroundings and modern drinks choices.

name: Tiger Inn
description:
City: East Dean
description: A frankly beautiful building dominating the village green, and also occupying part of it when the weather is good. Inside is a not yet ruined low ceilinged pub with chunky furniture and comfy corners, perhaps slightly bland. History with connection to smugglers.

name: Royal Hill
description:
City: Edgerley
description: Highly rated rustic country inn with typically low ceiling, tiled bar, stone floor, snooker and darts, outside seating and camping available.

name: Tolbooth Tavern
description:
City: Edinburgh
description: Didn't quite do enough on our visit, but there is reason to consider it. The striking building and its history alone justify popping by at least. Inside, comfortable and inviting, quite intimate interior with upholstered bench seating and carved wood bar., although not a standout for Edinburgh. (Added February 2024)

name: The White Hart Inn
description:
City: Edinburgh
description: Clearly a little touristy, it remains to be seen if the character of the place remains intact when the tourists descend and the cantine food emerges, but nevertheless, attractive wood beams and stylish decor look inviting and worth a look. Reportedly Edinburgh's oldest pub

name: The New Inn
description:
City: Flash
description: The highest village pub - apparently. 1518ft above sea level. 250 year heritage and reputation for cockfighting, counterfeiting and so on. While nothing of such ill-repute happens these days, it does appear to be an old fashioned boozer, a place the locals enjoy. The sign hanging above the bar: "Diane welcomes you to the madhouse'

name: The Camp House Inn
description:
City: Grimley
description: Beautifully unspoilt lived-in country pub with simple pleasures. Looks an absolute classic. Mind the peacock and geese around the grounds.

name: Stag Inn
description:
City: Hastings
description: Grade II listed timber-frame pub with a pleasant rustic cosy interior in keeping with the heritage of the building. It's also a little weird with mummified cats, witch decorations and local rituals, giving it all a distinctive feel. Very well reviewed.

name: The White Horse
description:
City: Hedgerley
description: Fantastic looking country pub with rave reviews. Beer poured directly from cask and recent orchard supplying local cidermakers. Fire blazes in winter. Two small intimate bars. Lovely garden. Everything a pub should be.

name: The Red Lion
description:
City: Hooe
description: An archetypal old Southern British pub overlooking the village green with picnic tables, while inside the trusty combo of beams, fireplace, stone floor and the patina of history. Some careful modernisation means it isn't totally jaw dropping but is worth a look if you're in the area.

name: Twa Dogs Inn
description:
City: Keswick
description: Very pleasant looking boozer with darts room festooned with scarves, wood pannelled bar and nice all-round appearance that is unpretentious and in keeping with the surroundings.

name: Running Horse
description:
City: Leatherhead
description: A 14th century timber-framed pub with sloping floors and ceilings and crooked fixtures, but remarkably even this place has been given a lick of that godawful grey/blue paint in one room. Nevertheless, some character appears to have remained to link the current venue to its past.

name: Sun Inn
description:
City: Leintwardine
description: Outstanding looking pub on CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. Adapted from a row of cottages c.1860, the old owner Flossie kept the place unchanged during a 74 year tenture. The heart of the pub remains in use despite a bright slate floored extention being added in 2011. The old parlour remains open unchanged.

name: The Hand at Llanarmon Ltd
description:
City: Llanarmon
description: Quaint stone walled pub with a recognisable country inn appearance. Low beamed snug bar, popular late nights for local farmers.

name: The Skirrid Mountain Inn
description:
City: Llanvihangel Crucorney
description: Wales' oldest pub, but more importantly, a success in terms of retaining the meaning of being that, with suitably timeless layout, low slug ceilings, stone walls, oak beams, flagstone floor and traditional decor.

name: Ye Old Mitre Inne
description:
City: Chipping Barnet
description: Narrow corridors, aging beams, atmospheric surroundings from a pub steeped in history, but with the current offerings tasteful and redolent of that. Timber framed, grade II listed and decent selection of traditional ales. Looks good.

name: The Carpenters Arms
description:
City: London
description: Successfully preserved corner pub with panelled walls, simple fireplace and bench seats. Narrow corridor leads to a rear room for more clandestine drinking.

name: The Blacksmith Arms
description:
City: Cudham
description: Lovely village pub converted from a farmhouse. Exposed beams and some 60s era signage at the bar give the main bar room character. Cosy and carpeted, available for drinkers as well as diners.

name: Prospect of Whitby
description:
City: London
description: Still a little dubious about whether this place has retained enough of interest, but we recommend it for the time being. Unfortunately in the clutches of Greene King.

name: Six Bells
description:
City: Wick
description: A 300 year old flint inn with gorgeous exposed beams, inglenook and cosy wooden surroundings. Looks fairly unspoilt so go now before they manage to ruin it.

name: Staggs (The Volunteer Arms)
description:
City: Musselburgh
description: Fantastic looking pub with light brown wood strip panel walls, vintage brewery mirrors and snug. Looks great from almost any angle.

name: Lollard's Pit Pub
description:
City: Norwich
description: A reasonably characterful town inn with exposed beams, carpets and intimate feel. Perhaps more of an all-rounder but we shall see.

name: The Hand & Heart
description:
City: Peterborough
description: Mixed reviews about the place but it has a one off bar area on CAMRA's national inventory, modernist in style, and seems to have a cast of locals and good selection of ales.

name: The White Horse
description:
City: Prior's Dean
description: Spectacular looking pub. As Bob Barton says 'a patina of antiquity', with half timbering, tree trunk counters, old fireplaces, bare stone, old plastic. AKA 'The Pub With No Name'

name: Rye Waterworks Micropub
description:
City: Rye
description: A unique location for a micropub. The place has been a pump house, a soup kitchen and public toilets, before becoming an antique shop. The latest incarnation shows its versatility. Of course, being a micropub, there are great ales in abundance. Interestingly, the antique shop still partly runs and customers can even make offers for the furniture if they like them.

name: The Haunch Of Venison
description:
City: Salisbury
description: The gastropub furnishings have taken over, slightly spoiling the otherwise medieval atmosphere. Different rooms called the House of Lords and the House of Commons and a truly attractive bar area still make this a distinctive venue worth seeking out.

name: Bridge Inn
description:
City: Santon Bridge
description: A typical northern country pub with thick carpet, exposed beams and, typical for these days anyway, relatively open plan in the main room. Looks to still retain character not just from outward appearances.

name: The Woolpack Inn
description:
City: Slad
description: An absolutely magnificent looking unspoilt rustic country pub with roaring hearth, wooden floors, ageing bench seats, piano and divided into different rooms. Tempting line up of ales and cider. Can't wait to go.

name: Dancing Man Brewery
description:
City: Southampton
description: Successful use of space, this old wool house has been converted into a brewery with visible equipment, warmly lit stone walls, and showpiece staircase. Plenty of memorabilia to fill the large space. Modern but tastefully done and useful for locals.

name: Duke of Wellington
description:
City: Southampton
description: Half-timbered house with beautifully preserved wooden bar. Both smart and historic, this is a clearly well executed and maintained pub.

name: The Red Lion
description:
City: Southampton
description: Pub in a medieval style great hall, called 'one of the treasures of our surviving medieval inns', there is a Tudor stone fireplace, exposed rafters, court room, flags and heraldry, etc. Also good ciders.

name: The North Star Inn
description:
City: Steventon
description: A heritage inn of England, customers are served from a ground floor cellar rather than a bar, alternatively a stable door and a hatch in the lounge will do. Outside seated are served from the kitchen window. Panelled walls, tile floor, wood framed snug with worn bench seats. Outhouse toilets. Traditional games. The ruritanial pub of your dreams, it seems.

name: The Stiperstones Inn
description:
City: Stiperstones
description: Ignore the dining rooms and head for the beautiful lounge. Rustic and cosy with fre beams, upholstered bench seating, horse brasses in typical country fashion. Rave reviews for the current owners and on CAMRA's regional inventory.

name: Nicky-Tams Bar & Bothy
description:
City: Stirling
description: Live music and cosy market tavern feel inside this bunker like venue, escape from the outside world, or 'grim reality' as it indicates towards your exit.

name: The Duke Of Wellington
description:
City: Wareham
description: Looks to be a classic example of an unspoilt authentic English market tavern. Unpretentious and not corporate or cookie cutter. Comfy, lived in and cosy.

name: The Schooner
description:
City: Gateshead
description: Lovely 'proper boozer' proving that being down to earth and good quality aren't mutually exclusive as Wetherspoons, Greene King and Sam Smiths would have you believe. The environment of a true local with a lived-in premises, live music, quiz, events, and versatile venue. Well reviewed, good ales on cask.

name: The Little R'Ale House
description:
City: Wellingborough
description: A station bar and micropub with a welcoming cosy looking bar area.

name: The Letter B
description:
City: Whittlesey
description: Not quite full information on the interior layout but this free house community local has great reviews for the quality of ales and warmth of welcome. Seems to be the best place in town.

name: The Rugglestone Inn
description:
City: Widecombe-in-the-Moor
description: Isolated beautiful pub with beer served directly from cask. Timeless beauty to the farm cottage type exterior to the genteel rustic exterior, which while new, is sympthetic and in keeping with the wider environment. Looks authentic and we'd love to go.

name: Tom Cobley Tavern
description:
City: Spreyton
description: Village pub cherished by locals, seemingly with good reason. A welcoming interior has not been swept away with recent fashions, but has kept itself homeless and unpretentious. Very well reviewed.

name: The Rose Tavern
description:
City: Wisbech
description: Traditional one room pub stripped back to its simple core. Drink, conversation and old time pub games.

name: The Draughtsman Alehouse
description:
City: Doncaster
description: Micro-pub at the train station serving an excellent range of ales. Limited seating but decent atmosphere supplemented by attractive tiled walls from what must have been a waiting room. Keeps limited hours.

name: John Fallon's "The Capstan Bar"
description:
City: Dublin
description: Attractive ale house. Fairly open plan by Irish bar standards but some nice wooden fittings, glow of light and conviviality. Popular with locals, slightly younger crowd perhaps. Worth a look.

name: Fallon's Bar
description:
City: Clonaslee
description: Lovely homely Irish pub. Could perhaps tone down the flags but there's a lot of authenticity on display

name: Fagans
description:
City: Moynalvey
description: A stop-off in the heart of the countryside. Authentic, raw, homely and lived.in. Well reviewed.

name: The Hanging Gate
description:
City: Chapel-en-le-Frith
description: An uncomplicated roadside inn with cosy interior, black wood furniture, carpet, fireplace and simple food and drinks. Looks ungentrified and authentic, therefore likely to be good.

name: The Barrel Drop
description:
City: Nottingham
description: Well rated central alehouse, looks to have a bit more about it than just the beers

name: The Lincolnshire Poacher
description:
City: Nottingham
description: Castle Rock Brewery tied pub with simple alehouse surroundings, fairly well rated

name: Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese Inn
description:
City: Castleton
description: Looks an excellent option with low beams and the sort of rustic country pub people seek out in this part of England.

name: Drink
description:
City: Hebden Bridge

description: A decent bottleshop/bar with tap and bottle selections and a few improvements to the decor. Close to warranting an addition to our guide but will give it a few more goes.

name: New Delight Inn
description:
City: Blackshaw Head

description: Looks like a terrific unspoiled country inn, without a thought towards bland dining room embellishments, all about the lived in cosy homely feel. Would like to visit very soon.

name: Shoot the Crows
description:
City: Sligo
description: Named after a pest control traditional, this is a pokey compact but hugely atmospheric pub known for quirky fittings and authentic Irish traditional music.

name: Walsh's
description:
City: Dublin
description: Looks a solid option. Relatively airy in the bar room but with a snug, stained glass, live music and a relatively timeless appearance you have a pub that's well loved.

name: Tigh Chóilí
description:
City: Galway
description: Excellent looking pub with clutter pinned to the bar fixtures and wall space filled with framed artwork and photos, along with god knows what else. Famous for its live music and also known to have a decent whisky selection.

name: McDermott's Pub
description:
City: Toomullin
description: Decent looking country pub with several rooms off a cluttered bar space. Barn-like in places but fairly cosy and non-corporate (aside the usual drinks options). Known for its particularly fervent and energetic live music performances.

name: The Board Inn
description:
City: Lealholm
description: Beloved village pub known for its live music performances, cask ales, riverside setting and pub grub. Interior looks undramatic but hints of a personal touch. This will demand a visit.

name: The Heron Bar and Restaurant
description:
City: London
description: The pub recovered most of the interior of the old Windsor Castle and despite the unprepossessing exterior there seems to be a serious reason to go here.

name: Ma Che Siete Venuti A Fà
description:
City: Rome
description: Beer mecca with some football leanings. Stickers on the entrance etc, but inside it is not a dangerous place by any means but a cosy hangout spot.

name: Wishful Drinking
description:
City: Rickmansworth
description: Very well reviewed bottleshop and bar. Interior looks reasonably good though still of its style, there is enough to pique the curiosity. We shall see.

name: The Old Ship Inn
description:
City: Bridlington
description: Pleasingly unchanged appearance with classic upholstered seating, carpets and cabinets, with the main concession to modernity being an improved drinks selection. That seems the right way around. Live music.

name: The Swan
description:
City: Little Totham
description: Fantastic looking village pub, in large thatched cottage with exposed beams. Plenty of personalised non-corporate signage, great reviews.

name: The Cat's Back
description:
City: London
description: Some of the original features are slowly sliding away as the modernising years take over, but there is still plenty to enjoy here by the look of it

name: Anchor Tap
description:
City: London
description: Well preserved Edwardian style corner pub with traditional features - plenty of colours in between black white yellow and brown, essentially. Looks cosy and well review. 
Warning: this is a Sam Smiths pub

name: The Kings Arms
description:
City: London
description: A bit of a mixture. The main room looks relatively uneventful, but an atrium area with distressed furniture and nik naks looks pretty good, and some original features remain in what appears to be a snug room.

name: The Royal Oak
description:
City: London
description: Unsure about this one. A Victorian corner pub with a very nice sweeping bar area in the centre. Need to visit to assess if it has become too bland. Harvey's beers.

name: The Cow
description:
City: London
description: Intriguing luncheon bar with seafood options, however more importantly there is a saloon where one can drink among some preserved Victorian environs.

name: The Swan at Milton
description:
City: Milton
description: Traditional pub with upholstered seating, red and green colours. Real ales and a personal touch. Not modernised but well kept. Decent looking beer garden too.

name: The Railway Arms
description:
City: Alton
description: Looks a true classic. More than one nod to the railway, but the general theme is rustic with real ales. Well review.

name: The Golden Pheasant
description:
City: Lower Farringdon
description: A homely and quite personalised pub here eschewing some of the more template formats, but still achieving a degree of warmth and welcome. Well reviewed.

name: The Harrow, Steep
description:
City: Steep
description: 17th century inn with garden, rustic yet plush interior, corners for drinking and not just an open dining room. Very attractive bar area. Well reviewed, and looks good.

name: Llandoger Trow
description:
City: Bristol
description: Preserved Tudor building which apparently might have a pub in? Nothing on Google but there are plenty of up-to-date references elsewhere.

name: Horská chata Na Perlíčku - Prdek, hospůdka, minipivovar a ubytování
description:
City: Paseky nad Jizerou
description: Very attractive looking brew pub with cabin/stone aesthetic. Cosy and a bit personalised too.

name: Cross Keys
description:
City: Eastgate
description: An ungentrified country inn with exposed beams lined with jugs, cushioned bench seating and carpets, fire going, pub grub. Unpretentious and homely. Very well reviewed.

name: Hare & Hounds
description:
City: Westgate
description: Looks a bonafide classic country inn. Ungentrified with exposed beams and tangible history. Impressive bar area with brass detail. Simple homely and unpretentious. Real fire. Pub grub. Exceptional reviews.

name: The Old Green Tree
description:
City: Bath
description: Attractive compact alehouse with wood panels and simple stripped back format. Nice plotting parlour side rooms. Some European beers in addition to ales. Looks very good.

name: The White Hart
description:
City: Truro
description: Half step down into this low ceilinged ale house. Post-covid, there looks to be potential here with some attractive preserved fixtures at the rear, chunky furniture and decent enough range of cask ales. Plenty of local life too.

name: De Hems Dutch Cafe Bar
description:
City: London
description: Dutch style brown cafe with certain features that bring to mind an Amsterdam pub. Overall it didn't impress us enough to make a final inscription but we will tentatively recommend going.

name: Bohemia House
description:
City: London
description: Interesting venue. Bohem brewery beers in a building with a long standing connection for Czechs and Slovaks in london. Grand townhouse with 'restaurant' which is actually very much like a Czech pub. Grand but extremely informal with table football, pool, TV, simple menu with Czech offerings and a decent supply of ex-pats. We will need to try a few more times before giving a final verdict.

name: Lowlander Grand Cafe
description:
City: London
description: A Belgian/Dutch style cafe with high ceiling, pillars and mezzanine level. Great range of drinks albeit at eye-poppingly expensive prices. The space becomes quite noisy and cacophonous when busy but can otherwise be pleasant. Needs a few more visits to make a final decision.

name: The Albert Inn Bridgetown Brewery
description:
City: Totnes
description: Lovely-looking trad ale house serving as the base for a local brewery. Distinctive slat-clad exterior and rustic furniture inside. Unfortunately closed when we tried to visit, but looks good.

name: Totnes Brewing Company
description:
City: Totnes
description: Lovely looking ale house that serves as the base for a local brewery. Simple brown and golds dominate. The building is prominent at the top of the long drag up the hill which again seems to amplify its status as a destination. Well reviewed. Closed when we tried to visit, however.

name: Red Lion
description:
City: Colwyn Bay

description: Attractive traditional neighbourhood pub with wood panels, bench seating, arrange of real ales and local life. Well reviewed + looks good.

name: The White Lion Inn
description:
City: Llanelian
description: Ungentrified country pub with an olde-world feel. Carpets, dark beams and furnishings, real fire, pub grub. Looks good, exceptionally well reviewed.

name: Thomas Connolly Bar
description:
City: Sligo
description: Fantastic looking preserved boozer that is a heritage building. Simple wooden ale house that has gained the worn patina of years and memories. Attractive bar area and partioned areas of seating off it. Ultra-minimalist furnishings.

name: The Pelican Inn (Wye Valley)
description:
City: Gloucester
description: Smashing-looking neighbourhood boozer with attractive bar area and great range of ales. Well reviewed.

name: Café René
description:
City: Gloucester
description: A beautifully put together venue with exposed beams and brasses, barrels and a bit of personalised quality. Looks great.

name: The Red Lion Inn
description:
City: Belchamp Otten

description: Highly personalised free house country inn with a homely feel, and space for drinking and socialising as well as food. Exceptionally well reviewed.

name: The Roseland Inn
description:
City: Philleigh-in-Roseland
description: Isolated country pub with a genteel garden and interior. Some attractive preserved features that haven't yet been gentrified. Fairly foody but looks like there are some spots for a drink and to socialise.

name: The Tinners Arms
description:
City: Zennor
description: Attractive country inn with genteel garden out front and more traditional interior that has been relatively well preserved, some space for drinking and socialising and not just dining. Well reviewed.

name: Pandora Inn
description:
City: Mylor
description: Attractive riverside inn that is served fresh catches by local fishermen. The downstairs is a well preserved dark wood affair. While foodie and fairy bland on the outside and in the upstairs, it does look good downstairs and appears to have ample space for drinking and socialising.

name: Rashleigh Inn
description:
City: Polkerris
description: Priceless beachside location (right onto the beach) but with a reasonably well preserved interior and operation that is trying to preserve local interest as well as tourists. It still looks to have something about it.

name: Ship Inn, Mousehole
description:
City: Mousehole
description: The central bar and rooms off it have been well preserved with blackened beams and bench seating, which serves as an enticing place for a drink.

name: The Golden Smog
description:
City: Stockton-on-Tees
description: Magnificent looking little alehouse, micropub with outstanding reviews. Simple seating and a personalised interior that is distinctive.

name: Den Gode Naboen AS
description:
City: Trondheim
description: Riverside pub with outdoor seating, but also cosy log-cabin type interior with low beams and plenty of wood. Ales aplenty, and great reviews.

name: Antikvariatet
description:
City: Trondheim
description: Attractive cafe bar with older stylings as you might guess from the name, a homely bookish feel with some instruments suggesting live music. Very well reviewed.

name: Grünerløkka Brygghus
description:
City: Oslo
description: Brewpub with a British-style appearance. Not in a tacky way thankfully, but instead with some thought put into layout and upholstery.

name: Hospůdka na Rychtě
description:
City: Valašské Meziříčí
description: Throwback hospoda - very local, so prepare yourself - with Rychtar beers and a typical authentic Czech atmosphere. It was close to making our guide on our one visit, and worth noting if you're in town. (Added October 2024)

name: Hospůdka v Židech
description:
City: Lomnice
description: Beautiful setting with outdoor seating and some home brew, perhaps need a bit more information about the interior, but looks promising.

name: Ye Olde Reine Deer Inn
description:
City: Banbury
description: Tacky sounding name but the pub appears to be a bit of a classic. Old 2-sided wooden bar with grand fireplace. Low ceilings, exposed beams, wooden bench seating. A lovely looking old fashioned market town inn.

name: The Walnut Tree
description:
City: Broad's Green
description: Excellent looking village pub with a stately timelessness that seems to have been a deliberate decision. All for the better.

name: East Cliff Tavern
description:
City: Folkestone
description: Very fabulous looking mid-terrace pub with unspoilt, genteel homely decor. Some cask ales available. Looks a bonafide classic.

name: Why Not ? Cafe-bar
description:
City: Worsley
description: Small cafe bar with beer options and a music leaning that looks reasonably individual and distinctive. Very well reviewed.

name: Hollybush Inn
description:
City: Breedon on the Hill
description: Other than some bland and inappropriately grey paint at the bar area, the pub looks great with a half timber exterior, low ceiling and beams inside. Very popular locally.

name: The Wonston Arms
description:
City: Sutton Scotney
description: Well loved free house and village pub with large outdoor area and nicely down to earth homely interior, attractive without being dramatic or flashy, with local life and good range of ales.

name: Bier Huis Grand Café
description:
City: St Ives
description: Attractive and relatively charming attempt to recreate a belgian bar, with the usual signage and ephemera, smart fitted bar and lamp lighting, mezzanine level.

name: The Dove, Hammersmith
description:
City: London
description: Historic Thameside pub with a famously small snug bar room, riverside seating and nice wooden beamed interior that retains a degree of historic character.

name: The Greyhound
description:
City: Saxton
description: Magnificent looking unspoilt country in with low ceilings, rustic nik naks, and glorious timewarp 1950s simplicity. WARNING: Sam Smiths pub

name: Burton Bridge Inn
description:
City: Burton upon Trent
description: An in all ways 'classic' pub with large fireplace, wooden fittings, beams, jugs, brasses, Simple and homely. Looks great.

name: The Little Plough
description:
City: Doncaster
description: Screams 'proper pub', although in Doncaster all bets are off. Carpeted interior with dartboard and classic lounge bar. Faienced frontage.

name: The Manor Castle
description:
City: Sheffield
description: Excellent unspoilt pub on CAMRA's national inventory next to ruins of a 16th century lodge. Not your typical out of town large inn, this is a corner boozer, down to earth, well reviewed.

name: Chantry Inn
description:
City: Handsworth
description: Info a little thin on the ground, but meant to be a strong choice for ales, down to earth neighbourhood pub, albeit one that is on CAMRA's national inventory.

name: The Gardener’s Arms
description:
City: Bilton
description: Superb looking unspoilt country inn with real fire, and timewarp atmosphere. WARNING: Sam Smiths pub.

name: The Crown Inn, Glossop
description:
City: Glossop
description: Unreconstructed backstreet boozer with simple furnishings and throwback atmosphere, real fire, homely. WARNING: Sam Smiths pub.

name: The Samuel Oldknow
description:
City: Marple
description: Attractive micro-pub/ale house with an intimate appearance and great selection of beers.

name: The Eyre Arms Old Eyre Arms
description:
City: Hassop
description: Beautiful traditional village pub. Has been closed under Covid but worth watching to see if it re-opens. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors.

name: The Shepherds Arms
description:
City: Whaley Bridge

description: Probably not going to be to everyone's tastes but this remains a drinks focused village boozer with attractive wood and leather fittings, on CAMRA's national inventory of interiors.

name: Hare & Hounds
description:
City: Manchester
description: Preserved century old interior and a still popular vibrant pub with a mixed city crowd. Fabulous tiling, leather and wood fittings along with distinctive side rooms. On a first visit it had a fair bit going for it, a distinctly working class character and possibly a bit cliquey unfortunate, however we are prepared to give it another try.

name: Coach & Horses
description:
City: Whitefield

description: Historic old boozer with modern and spacious beer garden. The interior has been preserved and is on CAMRA's national inventory. Despite a relatively low rating on Google, this appears to be due to a couple of low level incidents years ago. Most if not all recent reviews are very good.

name: The Turks Head
description:
City: Retford
description: Mock-tudor exterior and well preserved old-world interior on CAMRA's national inventory. Real ales. Looks to have carpeted floors, fire, bench seating, wood panels, a very good example of a specific style, essentially.

name: The Alexandra
description:
City: Stockport
description: Maybe not the first pub to go to in Stockport but nevertheless on CAMRA's interior inventory as a pub of national importance. A grand wooden bar area and mosaic floor gives the place a late Victorian/early Edwardian appearance, with some cosy siderooms. We aren't 100% sure about it but there's only one way to find out for sure. Robinsons beers.

name: Duke of York Inn, Elton
description:
City: Elton
description: 2021 Update: Possibly closed for whatever reason. Magnificent unchanged country pub that is normally only open in the evenings.

name: The Queen's Arms
description:
City: Patricroft
description: Extremely genteel, calm, plush and cosy neighbourhood pub with Queen Vic memorabilia and some retro signage and fittings too. On CAMRA's national inventory. Very well reviewed, a definite throwback.

name: The Sweet Green Tavern
description:
City: Bolton
description: Despite miserly (and possibly impoverished) locals bickering about the prices (note to readers: prices at Wetherspoons are abnormally low so get used to normal prices elsewhere) there does appear to be considerable charm about this place which attracts a mixed crowd with it's more old man preserved interior, dog friendliness and more modern outdoor area. Landlady seems to work very hard keeping it afloat.

name: Ye Olde Gate Inn
description:
City: Brassington
description: Classic country inn. While it has gone foody, the rustic furniture, old fireplace and cooker lend it plenty of charm. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors.

name: Harrington Arms Gawsworth
description:
City: Gawsworth
